awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Scientific Data in Schools: Measuring the efficacy of an innovative approach to integrating quantitative reasoning in secondary science
awd_abstract_narration:
The Discovery Research K-12 program (DRK-12) seeks to significantly enhance the learning and teaching of science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) by preK-12 students and teachers, through research and development of innovative resources, models and tools (RMTs). Projects in the DRK-12 program build on fundamental research in STEM education and prior research and development efforts that provide theoretical and empirical justification for proposed projects.

The goal of this project is to investigate whether the integration of real data from cutting-edge scientific research in grade 6-10 classrooms will increase  quantitative reasoning ability in the context of science. Data Nuggets are activity-based resources that address current needs in STEM education and were developed by science graduate students and science teachers at Michigan State University through prior support from the NSF GK-12 program and the BEACON Center for the Study of Evolution in Action. The goal of Data Nuggets is to engage students in the practices of science through an innovative approach that combines scientific content from authentic research with key concepts in quantitative reasoning. Partners from Michigan State University and BSCS will adapt the materials to address current science and mathematics standards, create a professional development program for teachers, and test the efficacy of the materials through a cluster-randomized trial in the classrooms of 30 teachers in Michigan, Colorado, and California. 

The project will study whether short, targeted interventions of classroom activities embedded within a typical curriculum can impact student outcomes. Prior to the study teachers will participate in professional development. Classrooms of the teachers in the study will be randomly assigned to either a treatment or comparison condition. Student outcome measures will include understanding of quantitative reasoning in the context of science, understanding of the practices and processes of science, student engagement and motivation, and interest in science.

In order to adequately train the next generation of citizens and scientists, research is needed on how quantitative reasoning skills build upon each other throughout K-16 science education Students need to experience activities that emphasize how science is conducted, and apply their understandings of how scientists reason quantitatively. Establishing the efficacy of Data Nuggets could provide the field with information about supplementing existing curriculum with short interventions targeted at particular scientific practices. By facilitating student access to authentic science, Data Nuggets bridge the gap between scientists and the public. Scientists who create Data Nuggets practice their communication skills and share both the process of science and research findings with K-12 students (and perhaps their families), undergraduates, and teachers, improving the understanding of science in society.

por.por_cntn:
Data Nuggets are brief classroom activities that engage students in the complexity of authentic scientific research through an introduction to real scientists and their stories. Originally conceptualized by teachers and graduate students participating in an NSF GK-12 project, and now including over 100 scientific contexts, Data Nuggets make visible the world of scientific research from the development of research questions and hypotheses, data collection, analysis of data, and developing scientific explanations. Teachers often embed the activities within a typical sequence of science instruction to provide students with a data-rich experience within the context of an associated content area. 

The Intellectual Merit of the Data Nuggets innovation is demonstrated through a randomized-control trial which measured the impact of Data Nuggets on student outcomes in quantitative reasoning, career motivation, self-efficacy in completing data-related tasks, interest in science, value of science to society, and engagement, compared to a group of students not using Data Nuggets. Students in the treatment and comparison groups improved similarly in quantitative reasoning over the course of the study, however we observed several differences for those using Data Nuggets when compared to students not using Data Nuggets. Students who used Data Nuggets spent more time engaged in the practices of science and increased their ability to construct explanations using data as evidence, compared to student not using Data Nuggets. Students who used Data Nuggets showed increased self-efficacy in data-related tasks and interest in STEM careers, potentially due to the scientist stories that run throughout each activity.

The Broader Impacts of this project point to the importance of developing opportunities for students to engage in real-world science contexts in the classroom. Development of classroom-based experiences that demystify the work of scientists and provide opportunities for students to make connections between data analysis and development of scientific explanations bridges the gap between content and practice.  The Data Nuggets also provide scientists with a platform for sharing their work beyond the scientific community that requires translation of complex science ideas and data to a form digestible for K-12 students.
